Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Plate and Intramedullary Nail Fixation for Displaced Midshaft Clavicle Fractures

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 120 patients with displaced midshaft clavicle fractures were enrolled

Participants.evidence: eligibility criteria including patients with displaced midshaft clavicle fractures

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either plate fixation (n=58) or intramedullary nail fixation (n=62)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of plate versus intramedullary nail fixation for displaced midshaft clavicle fractures

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was disability, assessed using the QuickDASH score at a minimum followup of 30 months

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed

Number_Randomised.evidence: 120 patients with displaced midshaft clavicle fractures were enrolled between January 2011 and August 2012

Number_Analysed.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either plate fixation (n=58) or intramedullary nail fixation (n=62)

Result_Outcome.evidence: QuickDASH scores indicated no significant difference between the plate (1.8 ± 3.6) and intramedullary nail groups (1.8 ± 7.2; mean difference, −0.7; 95% CI, −2.2 to 2.04; p=0.95)

Harms.evidence: No major complications, such as infections, implant breakage, nonunions, or refractures, occurred after the 1-year followup
